sub_topic: The self-similarity of the Gosper curve.
message_1: Suppose that we start with a Gosper curve (also known as a Peano-Gosper curve) of length 50 units. If we were to create a new curve by iterating the same process of adding smaller Gosper curves replacing the straight segments, how long would this new curve be after two iterations?
message_2:
A Gosper curve is a fractal curve that is generated by replacing each straight segment with a smaller Gosper curve. In each iteration, the length of the curve increases by a factor of 7/3.

After the first iteration, the length of the new curve will be (50 * 7/3) units.

After the second iteration, the length of the new curve will be (50 * 7/3) * (7/3) units.

So, the length of the new curve after two iterations will be:

50 * (7/3) * (7/3) = 50 * 49/9 = 2450/3 â‰ˆ 816.67 units.
